results.title: Blood sweat and tears. Vol. 1
results.creator_credit: Frank Seres and Frank Seres Productions
results.brief_description: Narrated by Chris Haywood, this first volume of the “Blood sweat and tears” series contains the following episodes: “Obsession” looks at the seemingly obsessive attention given to sport by both the Australian media and the general public: investigates the questions why are there are sometimes when you can’t get anything on television except sport? and why do most people believe Donald Bradman is the most famous Australian of all time? “Winners and losers” shows the fine line that exists between success and failure in the ruthless world of international sport. “Black diamonds” looks at the issues surrounding Aboriginal achievements in sport. “Kill the bastards” looks at why people immerse themselves in a wider Self - a crowd of supporters, joined at the heart, not the head, bound by the team colours - to whom the one thing that gives life meaning is belonging, even if it means defeat.

results.title: Blokes and sheds - Des
results.creator_credit: Sarah Wishart, SBS Independent, South Australian Film Corporation, Australian Film Commission, Robi Watt and Mark Thomson
results.brief_description:
One of 12 minidocos about blokes and their sheds in South Australia.
Des lives and works on his farming property in the historical German region of The Barossa Valley in South Australia. He has a hint of a German accent – all the more surprising since he is the third generation of his family born in Australia. There are many sheds on the property housing equipment that belonged to his father and grandfather before him. In a beautifully well-preserved hay thatched shed, a vast collection can be viewed as an almost historical “museum” to early farming technology. Des knows where everything is - although some of it has probably not been used for 20 or 30 years. But the equipment is still in working condition and we witness Des using a combination of that equipment as part of his working day. Based on the book by Mark Thomson.

results.title: Blood oath = Prisoners of the sun [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Stephen Wallace, Brian A. Williams, Denis Whitburn, Charles Waterstreet and Siege Productions
results.brief_description: The Ambon tribunal which tried 91 Japanese soldiers for war crimes against Australian prisoners during World War II provided the basis for the script co-written by the son of John Williams who was the Australian prosecuting officer (Captain Cooper in the film, played by Bryan Brown). The film attempts to portray the perplexing issue of war guilt, against the background of international power politics, through the rhetoric of courtroom drama. It can usefully be compared with the Japanese documentary “The Tokyo Trial” (1984), the second half of which deals with the trial of 28 alleged war criminals. Cast also includes George Takei, Terry O’Quinn, John Bach, John Polson, Russell Crowe, Toshi Shioya, John Clarke and Deborah Unger. In English and Japanese with English subtitles.

results.title: Blokes and sheds - Mariano
results.creator_credit: Mark Thomson, Sarah Wishart, SBS Independent, South Australian Film Corporation, Robi Watt and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description:
One of 12 minidocos about blokes and their sheds in South Australia.
Mariano is a senior member of the rapidly growing South Australian Sudanese community, many of whom have arrived in Australia to seek refuge from their country that has been torn apart by civil war. Mariano lives with his family in public housing with a medium sized backyard. When Mariano pulls up the roller door of his shed, it is full – absolutely full of second-hand clothes, household utensils, furniture and appliances. Mariano collects and stores these items, which have been donated by the public, in his shed and distributes them to families who have recently arrived in Australia. As Mariano says: “I don’t make things in my shed. Or maybe I do… I am making a community!”. Based on the book by Mark Thomson.

results.title: Blue Mountains: moving memories: 1920's - 1970's
results.creator_credit: National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
results.brief_description: The National Film and Sound Archive has assembled a superb compilation of historic footage which follows the growth and development of the Blue Mountains, one of the most spectacular natural features of the Australian continent. Original commentary has been retained and music selected by the NFSA has been added to the silent segments. The footage has been gleaned from home movies, documentaries and newsreels and amongst the many items of interest is the feature on Norman Lindsay’s house and garden.

results.title: Blokes and sheds - Khai
results.creator_credit: SBS Independent, South Australian Film Corporation, Australian Film Commission, Mark Thomson, Sarah Wishart and Robi Watt
results.brief_description:
One of 12 minidocos about blokes and their sheds in South Australia.
Khai is an established and well-respected contemporary furniture designer of Malaysian descent. Since he started out his 30-year relationship with furniture, first as an antique dealer, collector and restorer, then as a designer, Khai has discovered many styles of influence. Khai’s latest pieces have a distinctly Danish form. At the back of his retail shop, Khai’s basic galvanised iron shed/workshop is very simple and orderly – a reflection of his design sense. Lined with tools of the trade (chisels, hammers, sanding equipment etc) the shed also houses many projects in various stages of completion. Amongst the sounds of timber being sanded, hammered and polished we hear Khai recount his earlier years. He talks of how he started out and how, even as he travels the world collecting pieces, the place he longs to be is with his tools in the shed, wearing his apron. Based on the book by Mark Thomson.

results.title: Blokes and sheds - Saroop & Omer
results.creator_credit: SBS Independent, South Australian Film Corporation, Australian Film Commission, Mark Thomson, Sarah Wishart and Robi Watt
results.brief_description:
One of 12 minidocos about blokes and their sheds in South Australia.
Set in the lush Riverland in South Australia, we meet a Sikh man, Saroop, and his Bosnian friend, Omer. Saroop owns 400 acres of fruit growing land on the River Murray. He’s been there for 25 years after coming out from the Punjab. Saroop has several sheds with large tractors and spraying machinery as well as one open-sided shed where he and Omer work on repairing things and on long term experiments - such as the budcutting machine they have worked on for several years. They call this shed “Omer’s Lab”. Saroop and Omer work hard at reusing lots of existing scrap to construct new things and replace parts on others. They are extremely inventive and are proud they have saved hundreds of dollars by making things more mechanical and efficient. This interstitial explores the close friendship between two different cultural backgrounds. Based on the book by Mark Thomson.

results.title: Blood for Dracula [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Paul Morrissey, Andrew Braunsberg and Compagnia Cinematografica Champion S P A
results.brief_description: Another Paul Morrissey film presented by Andy Warhol. Here is the Dracula story with the usual search for virgin blood. This very corny and at times funny film is quite gory and blood thirsty. The virgins, that Dracula seeks so hungrily and travels so far to find, unfortunately can not be found as the family of young aristocratic women are no longer virgins. Dracula becomes ill after drinking their blood. There is the usual killing of Dracula scene where the ever hissing vampire is having arms and legs removed by an axe. The blood flows rapidly and still the vampire hisses. A mixture of the erotic and the satirical. Featuring performances by Roman Polanski and Vittorio De Sica.

results.title: Blue Ice
results.creator_credit: Phillip Garth Law, Film Australia and External Affairs
results.brief_description: A record of the 1954 Australian National Antarctic Research Expedition, which relieved the scientific stations at Macquarie and Heard Islands and established a new station at Mawson on MacRobertson Land in Australian Antarctic Territory. The film describes the expedition’s departure from Melbourne in December 1953 and follows its 12,000 mile journey through high seas and pack ice, providing an insight into daily life at the stations and the challenges presented by often-difficult conditions. There is stunning footage of towering icebergs and masses of penguins as well as aerial reconnaissance and surveillance.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Phillip Garth Law, Film Australia and External Affairs

results.title: Blokes and sheds - Mick
results.creator_credit: SBS Independent, South Australian Film Corporation, Australian Film Commission, Sarah Wishart, Mark Thomson and Robi Watt
results.brief_description:
One of 12 minidocos about blokes and their sheds in South Australia.
Mick’s obsession with trains began when he was a young boy growing up in Prague. He began constructing his model train world for his grandchildren many years ago. However, when they grew up and lost interest, Mick’s interest continued to grow. Mick’s shed contains another world. In it are miniature houses, people, trees and animals, all set around a train line with a “Swiss” alpine backdrop complete with snow capped mountains. Mick spends his time in his shed perfecting his miniature world and making continuous repairs, additions and alterations. Based on the book by Mark Thomson.
